title: National Progressive Party (Panama)
text:
The Progressive National Party (in <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a>: "Partido Progresista Nacional", PPN) was a <a href="Panama">Panama</a>nian <a href="conservative">conservative</a> <a href="nationalist">nationalist</a>, personalistic <a href="political%20party">political party</a>.
The Progressive National Party was created by <a href="Carlos%20Sucre%20Calvo">Carlos Sucre Calvo</a> in 1959. The PPN left the <a href="National%20Patriotic%20Coalition">National Patriotic Coalition</a> and registered as separate political parties.
<a href="Carlos%20Sucre%20Calvo">Carlos Sucre Calvo</a> was a faction leader in the <a href="National%20Patriotic%20Coalition">National Patriotic Coalition</a> during <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">José Antonio Remón Cantera</a>'s tenure, and later served as education minister in 
<a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">Ernesto de la Guardia</a> (1958–1959) cabinet
and <a href="Marco%20Aurelio%20Robles">Marco Aurelio Robles</a>' (1966–1967 and 1968) cabinet.
In 1960, PPN allied with the <a href="Popular%20Alliance%20%28Panama%29">Popular Alliance</a> (AP) and its candidate <a href="V%C3%ADctor%20Florencio%20Goyt%C3%ADa">Víctor Florencio Goytía</a>.
In 1964, PPN allied with the <a href="National%20Opposition%20Union%20%28Panama%29">National Opposition Union</a> (UNO) and its candidate <a href="Marco%20Aurelio%20Robles">Marco Aurelio Robles</a>.
In 1964, PPN allied with the <a href="People%27s%20Alliance%20%28Panama%29">People's Alliance</a> (ADP) and its candidate <a href="David%20Samudio%20%C3%81vila">David Samudio Ávila</a>.
The PPN was abolished after a military coup in 1968.
